subject: Art & Design
title: Greek Columns: The Three Classical Orders
description: One-minute skill: Greek Columns: The Three Classical Orders.

hook.text: Walk past any courthouse, bank, or parliament and you'll see Greek columns. A 2,500-year-old design, still used.

buildup.text: The three Greek orders: Doric (simple), Ionic (scrolled), and Corinthian (ornate leaves). Each has a distinct look.

discovery.text: Doric says strength. Ionic says knowledge. Corinthian says wealth. Architects chose based on a building's purpose.

twist.text: The Parthenon's columns aren't straight. They bulge slightly in the middle to correct an optical illusion.

climax.text: Romans added Tuscan and Composite orders. But the original three remain architecture's most recognized forms.

punchline.text: Three column styles. Thousands of years. Still the language of authority.
